climbs.name: Do I Look Fat In This?

content.description:
Full value climbing that requires 5.9 proficiency in many sizes and techniques, going from thin techy tips and face, to fingers, hands, a little OW, an optional squeeze, and some stemming and chimneying to round things out. Get on it!  

Starts at the top of a small dirt ramp in the middle of the crag. The progressively widening crack with a dead stump about halfway up. 
Gear to 3", tiny cams for the start

Climb a right leaning finger/hand crack up into an alcove below a roof. Unlock a sequence that gives way to a beautiful dihedral above and left of the roof. Save a hand sized piece for this final push to the anchors.



On the ledge with 2 belay anchors. Easier accessed from the right.

Standard rack, doubles from .5 to #2 useful.

Head right through the roof, finish up hand crack above.


SR to 3"

Up an easier and slightly mossy crack to the base of the off-width. Clip a bolt out right, head out onto the face and into the right-leaning thin hands crack.



You'll see a large 'A' shape on the wall. Start at the base of the right side of the A.

SR to 3", one bolt, chains at the top.

up parallel cracks, two ways to get through the crux; layback or face climb further right. Good gear before and after the crux, poor to no gear mid-crux. Continue up finger to hand crack to finish. 



far end climbers right. Obvious parallel cracks, left of bolted line.

SR to #2, small cams

Start up a crack and work over a bulge to the right, into a wide right facing crack. The wide right facing crack near the left side of the crag, but not completely at the end of the wall

Gear up 4-5", chains at the top

also numbered route 22 on the topo. Twin crack system in the middle of the crag at the base of a couple of large trees. The route goes straight up but it's important to note there are 2 other variations: routes 24 and 25, both 5.8 that go up and right, or up and further right. There's also a 5.11- route that goes up next to this route and crosses over the other two variations. 

also numbered route 22 on the topo. Twin crack system in the middle of the crag at the base of a couple of large trees.
gear to 3"

Climb a right facing corner through a variety of styles. It starts tight hand crack, but changes in character after a mid-pitch ledge, and then again at the top.



Near the right side of the crag is an obvious left-trending ramp where a few climbs start. Payback starts on the next crack left of that ramp.

Many people will appreciate a double rack on this from BD .3-3, and one .2, 4.

climbs.name: Seven Habits of Highly Annoying People

content.description:
The obvious diagonal crack going up and left across the face of Upper Splitsville. 

Pull a move off the ground to gain an easy ramp. Approach the bulge, sink your hands in, and move up and left across the face with good jams and gear. Pull through the bulge (crux) back onto another ramp and continue up and left to the chains of Smile... or continue straight up any of the variations. 

Burly hand jams! Fun! 



Start ~15ft to the right of Payback and continue up and left 

Standard rack. Doubles in hand sizes.

climbs.name: Smile... And No One Will See How Broken You Are Inside

content.description:
Left leaning crack (number 26 on the topo downloaded from quickdraw publications)

A slightly left leaning crack toward the right side of the crag, the base is near a small step.
gear to 3"

climbs.name: Splitting Up is Hard to Do.

content.description:
A tricky corner (with some potentially uninspiring gear) leads to a small roof and then into a splitter hand crack. The route can seep a bit at the top of the first corner, and just below the chains, but it seems there are options to avoid the wet spots. This is a good climb with basically a perfect long hand crack guarded by the opening corner.



Look for a large blocky roof at mid-height on the wall. This route starts up the corner that goes to the right edge of the roof. It starts on ground lower than the neighbouring climbs on the right.

A standard rack to BD #3, doubling up on 1s and 2s.

Work a right leaning finger and hand crack for a few meters, then veer left and reach a beautiful but shallow hands splitter. The obvious crux awaits as the crack gets thin below the anchor.



This climb along with Going Separate Ways start on the ledge which has belay anchors on it. It is easier accessed from the right.

Standard rack, doubles of 0.75 and #1 are helpful. Small nuts and offset nuts will make you happy.

Nice mixed route, with a bouldery crux right at the beginning. The rest is a pleasant crack that is certainly below the grade. Favors taller climbers.



Adjacent to the One Thumb Up, on the left. Shares the same anchor.

4 bolts, half a standard rack
The far right of the crag (the higher end), off the left of the main trail.
